Award.AwardTitle: A Cellular Systems Analysis of Microbe-Arsenic Interactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United Nations designated 2005-2015 as an International Decade for Action: "Water for Life", with the intent of focusing attention of world governments on the declining availability of freshwater fit for human use. The severe arsenic contamination crisis in much of Asia is the most high profile example of this problem, though there are regions in the United States that also suffer from elevated arsenic in drinking water supplies. The fate, mobility, and ecotoxicology of arsenic in soil and water is highly dependent on the abiotic and biotic processes that regulate arsenic biogeochemical cycling in nature. It is now known that microbially catalyzed redox transformations are very important in controlling arsenic chemistry in most environments, and thus for reliable prediction of how and why arsenic moves within and across environments it is essential that microbe-arsenic interactions be understood in detail. The information generated from this study is expected to be of value to land and water resource managers in agriculture, mine reclamation, and municipal water treatment, finding application to bioremediation efforts aimed at manipulating microbe-As interactions in the environment and thus controlling As fate and transport. The project will include training opportunities for two Ph.D. graduate students that will include an international lab rotation in China, as well as undergraduate research internships targeting Native American students. In addition, the PIs will work with K-12 teachers to expand public and private school curricula by offering class period lectures and day-long microscopy based exercises that emphasize the importance of microorganisms to environmental health and function.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION. Research momentum established from previous NSF funding has now led to next-generation studies in this project that aim to comprehensively define how microbes react to arsenite in terms of total gene expression and how that then translates into perturbation of cellular biochemical pathways. The project focuses on an environmentally relevant bacterium, using specific strains that are defective in key genes that encode functions associated with arsenite detecting and regulating gene expression responses to arsenite. The organism to be studied, A. tumefaciens strain5A, is representative of microorganisms routinely isolated from arsenic-contaminated environments worldwide. By comparing arsenite responses of these strains to the original wild-type organism, the PIs will be able to define the different cellular response circuits, and how they are different or integrated. There are three objectives that frame the research. Objective 1 will use RNA-Seq technology to characterize the complete transcriptional circuit board of the three major AsIII sensing systems. Objective 2 will employ metabolomics to characterize metabolite profiles for the same microbial genotypes in order to define the full effects of AsIII on bacterial cell metabolism and to link gene expression to actual metabolism and cell behavior. Objective 3 efforts will use computational methods to integrate the metabolomics and transcriptomics data into a cellular systems format for predicting and interpreting metabolic strategies and electron fates as a function of AsIII exposure. Data generated from this study will have immediate, foundational impacts on our understanding of how bacteria react to metal(loids) in their environment, whether the environment is mine tailings, groundwater or soil.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background: The United Nations designated 2005-2015 as an International Decade for Action: ‘Water for Life’, with the intent of focusing attention of world governments on the declining availability of freshwater fit for human use. The severe arsenic contamination crisis in much of Asia is the most high profile example of this problem, although there are regions in the United States that also experience elevated arsenic in drinking water supplies. The fate, mobility, and ecotoxicology of arsenic in soil and water is dependent on the abiotic and biotic processes that influence arsenic biogeochemical cycling in nature. It is known that microbially catalyzed redox transformations are very important in controlling arsenic chemistry in most environments, and thus for reliable prediction of how and why arsenic moves within and across environments it is essential that microbe-arsenic interactions be understood in detail.

This study built upon the momentum established by prior work supported by the National Science Foundation.  It generated next-generation studies that comprehensively defined how microbes react to arsenite (As(III)) in terms of total gene expression (i.e. transcriptomics) and how that then translates into perturbation of cellular biochemical pathways (i.e. metabolomics). The project used an environmentally relevant soil bacterium (Agrobacterium tumefaciens) that we have been developing as a model organism for this type of study.  This bacterium is representative of microorganisms routinely isolated from arsenic-contaminated environments worldwide. Thus, it represents an ecologically–relevant model organism for studies aimed at predicting how bacterial metabolism is influenced and disrupted in situ by As(III), and for determining the broader implications for biogeochemical cycling in nature when microbes must deal with arsenic (e.g., we found that carbon and nitrogen cycling are impacted by arsenic contamination). For this work we used specific strains that are defective in key genes that encode functions associated with As(III) detection and that regulate gene expression responses to As(III). By comparing As(III) responses of these strains to the original wild-type organism, we were able to define the different cellular response circuits, and how they are different or integrated.

Intellectual Merit and Outcomes: We developed and used different mutants that are defective for the three known  proteins bacteria use for detecting As(III).  These mutants were used in gene expression experiments that examined the entire genome with respect to gene expression. RNA-Seq technology was used to generate and sequence millions of mRNA molecules that characterizes the complete regulatory circuit board of the major As(III) sensing systems. RNA-Seq is the most sensitive approach for detecting differences in gene expression, allowing us to dig deeply into understanding the first steps in how a bacterium responds to As(III) in its environment.  The project also employed state-of-the-art instrumentation, Mass Spectrometry, to assess how these gene expression changes translate to cellular biochemistry. This tells us how the cell is actually changing with respect to functional biochemistry.  We then used the results of these techniques to build models as a means of summarizing these cellular responses that can be used to understand arsenic cycling in nature. 

From this we learned that As(III) dramatically influences the expression of genes that are involved in numerous cellular activities that go well beyond current understandings of how arsenic will affect microbial metabolism.  Virtually every aspect of cell metabolism is impacted.  A few examples of cell responses include: copper resistance, iron acquisition and homeostasis, carbon metabolism, amino acid metabolism, phage biology and bacterial conjugation.  This represents new discoveries.  Further, we learned that for some As(III) transformations, such as As(III) oxidation), the cell must first be experiencing phosphate starvation, which represents an environmental factor that can be manipulated by land/water managers to control arsenic behavior.  From the metabolomics experiments we learned that carbon metabolism is significantly impacted, with the result being that normal routes of metabolism are diverted in ways that could impact carbon metabolism in nature. 

Data generated from this study is expected to have immediate, foundational impacts on our understanding of how bacteria react to As(III) in their environment, regardless of whether the environment is mine tailings, groundwater or soil. From this study, we learned that arsenic contamination in the environment carries multiple consequences.  In addition to being toxic to humans and all life forms, we have determined that arsenic impacts all aspects of microbial metabolism that in turn alters all aspects of environmental biogeochemistry.

Broader Impacts. The information generated from this study should find application to bioremediation efforts aimed at controlling arsenic fate and transport, and hence ecotoxicology. In addition, the study provided advanced training opportunities for one postdoc, two graduate students (one PhD and one MSc), two MSU undergraduate students, eight NSF REU students, one Chinese rotation student, and two high school students.  Further, the faculty involved worked with Native American students at the Aaniiih Nakoda Tribal College, and conducted one-day microbiology classes to local high schools and grade schools.
